sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: PicNode API provides access to a vast collection of images from places, football clubs, and icons. This guide will help you get started with integrating our APIs into your application.

sections.title: Base URL
sections.content: All API requests should be made to: https://a2insights.com.br/api/picnode

sections.title: Common Parameters
sections.content:
Most endpoints support the following parameters:
- `media_conversions`: Request specific image sizes (xs, sm, md, lg, preview, thumbnail, webp)
- `include`: Request related resources (e.g., media, mediaCount)
- `has_media`: Filter resources that have media attached

sections.title: Quick Start
sections.content: To start using the API, you'll need an authentication token. Once you have your token, you can make requests to any of our available endpoints.

sections.title: Available Endpoints
sections.content:
We provide the following endpoints:
- /companies - Company information
- /companies/{id} - Specific company details
- /places - Geographic locations with images
- /places/types - Types of places available
- /football-clubs - Football club logos and images
- /thing-icos - Icon collection

sections.title: Response Format
sections.content: All responses are returned in JSON format with pagination support. Each response includes data, links for navigation, and metadata about the current page.

sections.title: Rate Limiting
sections.content: To ensure fair usage and system stability, we implement rate limiting. We recommend implementing exponential backoff for retries and caching responses when possible.

sections.title: Error Handling
sections.content: Always implement proper error handling in your application. Our API returns standard HTTP status codes and detailed error messages in the response body.

sections.title: Efficient Pagination
sections.content: Use the page parameter to navigate through results. The API returns metadata including current_page, last_page, and total items to help you implement efficient pagination.

sections.title: Media Optimization
sections.content: Request specific media conversions using the media_conversions parameter to get optimized image sizes for your use case. Available sizes: xs, sm, md, lg, preview, thumbnail, webp.
sections.code:
// Request only small and medium conversions
fetch('https://a2insights.com.br/api/picnode/places?media_conversions=sm,md&has_media=1')

sections.title: Implement Caching
sections.content: Cache API responses to reduce redundant requests and improve application performance. Set appropriate cache expiration times based on your data freshness requirements.

sections.title: Search Optimization
sections.content: Use the filter[search] parameter efficiently. Implement debouncing on the client side to avoid excessive API calls during user input.

sections.title: Authentication Overview
sections.content: PicNode API uses Bearer token authentication. You must include your authentication token in the Authorization header of every request.

sections.title: Obtaining Your Token
sections.content: You can find your authentication token in your dashboard under the Tokens section. Keep your token secure and never expose it in client-side code or public repositories.

sections.title: Token Scopes
sections.content: When creating a token, you can restrict its access to specific APIs. The allowed APIs are: `thing-icos`, `places`, `football-clubs`, and `companies`.

sections.title: Using Your Token
sections.content: Include your token in the Authorization header with the Bearer scheme for every API request.

sections.title: Security Best Practices
sections.content:
• Never commit tokens to version control
• Store tokens in environment variables
• Rotate tokens periodically
• Use different tokens for development and production
• Implement token refresh mechanisms

sections.title: Handling Authentication Errors
sections.content: If your token is invalid or expired, the API will return a 401 Unauthorized response. Always check for this status code and handle it appropriately in your application.

sections.title: Server-Side Requests
sections.content: For server-side applications, store your token in environment variables and never expose it to the client side. Make API calls from your backend to keep tokens secure.
